text:
am I the only one who can never use Makie?

```(tmp) pkg> build GLMakie
    Building ModernGL → `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/326957556e9cc9253615114c04bb0096a2a69bb8/build.log`
    Building FFTW ────→ `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/1b48dbde42f307e48685fa9213d8b9f8c0d87594/build.log`
    Building GLMakie ─→ `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/d2b2a34539df91432c3f7ecbb8b432929f75e9b9/build.log`
  Progress [========================================>]  5/5
5 dependencies successfully precompiled in 84 seconds (125 already precompiled)

[...]

julia> scene = lines(x, y1, color = :blue)
Error showing value of type AbstractPlotting.FigureAxisPlot:
ERROR: No backend available (GLMakie, CairoMakie, WGLMakie)!
Maybe you imported GLMakie but it didn't build correctly.
In that case, try `]build GLMakie` and watch out for any warnings.
If that's not the case, make sure to explicitely import any of the mentioned backends.```
84 seconds to successfully build and precompile 5 (!) packages and then it doesn't work because building... failed (???)

elements.text: am I the only one who can never use Makie?

(tmp) pkg> build GLMakie
    Building ModernGL → `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/326957556e9cc9253615114c04bb0096a2a69bb8/build.log`
    Building FFTW ────→ `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/1b48dbde42f307e48685fa9213d8b9f8c0d87594/build.log`
    Building GLMakie ─→ `~/.julia/scratchspaces/44cfe95a-1eb2-52ea-b672-e2afdf69b78f/d2b2a34539df91432c3f7ecbb8b432929f75e9b9/build.log`
  Progress [========================================>]  5/5
5 dependencies successfully precompiled in 84 seconds (125 already precompiled)

[...]

julia> scene = lines(x, y1, color = :blue)
Error showing value of type AbstractPlotting.FigureAxisPlot:
ERROR: No backend available (GLMakie, CairoMakie, WGLMakie)!
Maybe you imported GLMakie but it didn't build correctly.
In that case, try `]build GLMakie` and watch out for any warnings.
If that's not the case, make sure to explicitely import any of the mentioned backends.
84 seconds to successfully build and precompile 5 (!) packages and then it doesn't work because building... failed (???)

text: I Just tried the latest registered GLMakie on Julia 1.5.3. Precompilation takes forever (I didn’t time it) but a simple plot works fine for me.

text: (I’m on macOS)

text: Can you try CairoMakie as a sanity check? GLMakie has the most issues because OpenGL is so fickle across systems. And yes precompilation is super long, I guess it became even longer when we added MakieLayout into it. We didn't spend much time yet on optimizing that because at least for me, features are more important. Kind of nonsensical to have a faster loading package that can't do what you want

text: <@UK1BNFHFV> While I share the sentiment, I would hope that Makie would also stabilize at some point. So far I have always seen it as super promising but “experimental”. I could never really recommend it to anyone. A plotting package is not only defined by its features but also by stability/usability. Look at matplotlib for example whose 3D capabilities are poor at best.

elements.text: While I share the sentiment, I would hope that Makie would also stabilize at some point. So far I have always seen it as super promising but “experimental”. I could never really recommend it to anyone. A plotting package is not only defined by its features but also by stability/usability. Look at matplotlib for example whose 3D capabilities are poor at best.

text: I hope this too. I would love to build Makie into a bunch of packages. like geospatial plotting in GeoData.jl, and live interactive visualisations in DynamicGrids.jl. But I just cant take on the maintenance load of dealing with the code churn. Plots.jl+Interact.jl is reliable and stable, so that's what gets used.

elements.text: I hope this too. I would love to build Makie into a bunch of packages. like geospatial plotting in GeoData.jl, and live interactive visualisations in DynamicGrids.jl. But I just cant take on the maintenance load of dealing with the code churn. Plots.jl+Interact.jl is reliable and stable, so that's what gets used.

text: I have really no more time than for creating the features that I want currently. I mean before MakieLayout we didn't even have the ability to do consistently looking subplots. Basically for me there is no point in spending effort on the project if it ends up stable without the features that I need from it. I understand your perspectives, too, but there are too many backend issues yet to tackle for us to promise stability. And Julia just makes it really difficult to construct a project of this size with the latency people expect for plotting

elements.text: I have really no more time than for creating the features that I want currently. I mean before MakieLayout we didn't even have the ability to do consistently looking subplots. And Julia just makes it really difficult to construct a project of this size with the latency people expect for plotting

text: I'd really love to try Makie out, lots of people are enthusiast about it, but I just can't even get past the first command of a basic example, and for me it has been like this forever.  since for my limited plotting needs `Plots` is enough I don't feel the need to invest more time on `Makie`.  but every time I say "let's see if I can finally see a basic plot" I get into troubles with something fundamental

text: I wouldn't recommend makie for that use case. Its strengths are its layout system and its interactivity / OpenGL speed for larger datasets. For simple plots there is no reason to try something else than the established solutions. Still, I'm surprised cairomakie didn't work, what was the problem there?

elements.text: I wouldn't recommend makie for that use case. Its strengths are its layout system and its interactivity / OpenGL speed for larger datasets. For simple plots there is no reason to try something else than the established solutions. Still, I'm surprised cairomakie didn't work, what was the problem there?

text: <https://julialang.slack.com/archives/C67TK21LJ/p1613398252343200?thread_ts=1613395360.338200&cid=C67TK21LJ>

Julius, that’s fair enough. It’s incredible work from your guys already. I just think that stability (more so than latency) is important if you guys want to take Makie to the next level and establish it as a “workhorse plotting package”. Maybe you don’t have the time for it, maybe you don’t want it. All fair enough. Personally, I just hope that Makie won’t stay in the “experimental” state forever :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Julius, that’s fair enough. It’s incredible work from your guys already. I just think that stability (more so than latency) is important if you guys want to take Makie to the next level and establish it as a “workhorse plotting package”. Maybe you don’t have the time for it, maybe you don’t want it. All fair enough. Personally, I just hope that Makie won’t stay in the “experimental” state forever

text: Ah <@UDB26738Q> you tried old syntax where you receive a scene from your first plotting call, now with the layout stuff we return a FigureAxisPlot. Please check the examples from the latest docs, not from the gallery or any other source. With the recent backend changes, many old examples floating around are not quite correct anymore.

elements.text: Ah

you tried old syntax where you receive a scene from your first plotting call, now with the layout stuff we return a FigureAxisPlot. Please check the examples from the latest docs, not from the gallery or any other source. With the recent backend changes, many old examples floating around are not quite correct anymore.
